message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, especially the pruritic rash and subcutaneous nodules, suggest Onchocerciasis, which is also known as river blindness. The presence of motile microfilariae on skin snip biopsy is consistent with this diagnosis. Lymphatic filariasis also presents with skin changes and subcutaneous nodules, but without the characteristic rash. Cysticercosis presents with cystic lesions in various organs, while cutaneous larva migrans presents with linear or serpiginous tracks on the skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pruritic rash and the presence of nontender subcutaneous nodules suggest Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. Lymphatic filariasis is also a possibility, but it typically presents with swelling of the legs, scrotum or breasts in both men and women. Cysticercosis presents with neurologic symptoms caused by cysts in the brain, whereas cutaneous larva migrans presents with an erythematous papular pruritic rash caused by migration of hookworm larvae under the skin. The definitive diagnosis for Onchocerciasis is made by the microscopic examination of skin snip biopsy specimens.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history of the patient suggest onchocerciasis, which is caused by the parasitic worm Onchocerca volvulus and results in subcutaneous nodules, pruritic rash, and difficulty reading due to eye involvement. The skin snip biopsy with motile microfilariae confirms the diagnosis. Lymphatic filariasis also presents with subcutaneous nodules and microfilariae, but typically involves the lower extremities rather than shoulders and buttocks. Cysticercosis and cutaneous larva migrans have different presentations and are not caused by Onchocerca volvulus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including the pruritic rash, hyperpigmentation, and subcutaneous nodules, suggest Onchocerciasis (also known as River blindness), which is caused by the parasitic filarial worm Onchocerca volvulus. Skin snip biopsies are taken to confirm the diagnosis by finding microfilariae in the incubated samples. Lymphatic filariasis can also cause microfilariae in skin samples, but it typically presents with lymphedema and elephantiasis. Cysticercosis and cutaneous larva migrans are caused by different parasites and present with different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the presence of microfilariae suggest Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. Lymphatic filariasis also involves microfilariae, but the symptoms and distribution of skin lesions are different. Cysticercosis involves tapeworm larvae and Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by dog or cat hookworm larvae.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including pruritic rash and subcutaneous nodules, are suggestive of Onchocerciasis. The presence of motile microfilariae confirms the diagnosis as Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. Lymphatic filariasis is another type of filariasis but has different symptoms. Cysticercosis is caused by Taenia solium and presents with cysts in different organs. Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by dog or cat hookworm larvae and presents with a serpiginous rash.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including pruritic rash, patchy hyperpigmentation, and subcutaneous nodules along the iliac crest, are consistent with Onchocerciasis. Microscopic examination of the skin snip biopsy showing motile microfilariae is also a characteristic of Onchocerciasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the presence of microfilariae on skin snip biopsy suggest onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. Lymphatic filariasis may also present with similar symptoms but is more commonly seen in Africa, while onchocerciasis is more commonly seen in Central and South America. Cysticercosis and cutaneous larva migrans do not present with microfilariae on skin snip biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the pruritic rash, difficulty reading, inguinal lymphadenopathy, and subcutaneous nodules, suggest onchocerciasis, which is caused by the parasite Onchocerca volvulus. The skin snip biopsy test aided in confirming the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of papules, excoriation marks, patchy hyperpigmentation, lymphadenopathy, and subcutaneous nodules suggest Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. The incubation of skin snip biopsies in saline revealed the presence of motile microfilariae, which are characteristic of Onchocerciasis. The other options do not match the clinical presentation and diagnostic findings.
